docs.lead_paragraph: Could there be a doctor in the house? In an effort to quiet complaints from doctors in its network, Oxford Health Plans is looking at a doctor to run the company.

headline.main: Oxford Considers Doctor as Chief and Gets Big New Investor

docs.abstract: Troubled Oxford Health Plans reportedly seeks doctor to run company in bid to quiet complains from doctors in network; Norman C Payson reportedly is leading candidate; mutual fund manager Michael Price's Franklin Mutual Advisors reports amassing 5 percent of Oxford; news spurs sharp rise in Oxford stock; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Could there be a doctor in the house?    In an effort to quiet complaints from doctors in its network, Oxford Health Plans is looking at a doctor to run the company.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration said today that it would be willing to give tobacco companies limited protection from lawsuits if that was the only way to get legislation enacted to raise the price of cigarettes and force the industry to restrict advertising and marketing. In the first Administration testimony since Congress began seriously considering tobacco legislation this year, David W. Ogden, the counselor to Attorney General Janet Reno, told the House Judiciary Committee that ''reasonable provisions modifying the civil liability of the tobacco industry would not be a deal-breaker.''

headline.main: Clinton Could Abide Protection for Cigarette Makers

docs.abstract: David W Ogden, counselor to Atty Gen Janet Reno, tells House Judiciary Committee that Clinton Administration would be willing to give tobacco companies limited protection from lawsuits if that was only way to get legislation enacted to raise price of cigarettes and force industry to restrict advertising and marketing (M)
docs.snippet: The Clinton Administration said today that it would be willing to give tobacco companies limited protection from lawsuits if that was the only way to get legislation enacted to raise the price of cigarettes and force the industry to restrict...

docs.lead_paragraph: Markdowns Help Retailers Lift Post-Holiday Sales Post-holiday clearance promotions by specialty clothing stores helped overall retail sales rise 5.9 percent last month, far higher than the 3.5 percent gains widely expected.
docs.snippet: Markdowns Help Retailers Lift Post-Holiday Sales  Post-holiday clearance promotions by specialty clothing stores helped overall retail sales rise 5.9 percent last month, far higher than the 3.5 percent gains widely expected.

docs.lead_paragraph: Government fraud investigators are trying to unravel a widening scheme in which phony medical bills using the names of unsuspecting patients and doctors are being submitted to private insurers. Investigators say the fake bills are sent out by fictitious companies that pretend to be medical practices or their billing agencies. These entities operate for a few weeks, using postal boxes for their return addresses, then shut down and reopen elsewhere under different names.

headline.main: Unwitting Doctors and Patients Exploited in a Vast Billing Fraud

docs.abstract: Government fraud investigators are trying to unravel widening scheme in which phony medical bills using names of unsuspecting patients and doctors are being submitted to private insurers; say fake bills are sent out by fictitious companies that pretend to be medical practices or their billing agencies; say these entities operate for few weeks, using postal boxes for their return addresses, then shut down and reopen elsewhere under different names; estimate that fraud has already resulted in over $1 billion in fake claims to scores of insurers; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Government fraud investigators are trying to unravel a widening scheme in which phony medical bills using the names of unsuspecting patients and doctors are being submitted to private insurers.    Investigators say the fake bills are sent out by...

docs.lead_paragraph: Although the stakes were not as high as in the uprising of the 20,000 female shirtwaist workers in 1909 or the divisive New York City teachers' strike of 1968, the four-year strike against the Box Tree restaurant also earned a page in the annals of New York's labor history. And now, it seems, the last of that page can finally be written.

headline.main: Bitter Strike Settled at Box Tree Restaurant; Workers Gain Health and Pension Benefits After Four Years of Picketing

docs.abstract: Four-year strike against Box Tree restaurant in Mnahattan is ended; Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union declares victory in action that symbolized tense labor-management relations facing many low-wage and immigrant workers; union says management has agreed to demands for workers' health insurance, pensions and grievance procedure, after originally refusing to discuss those matters; Henry J Tamarin, president of union local, says Box Tree settlement will help dozens of efforts to unionize restaurants throughout New York area; Box Tree's owner, Augustin Paege, had called strikers 'fascists' and pledged never to sign contract; union signed contract with Box Tree's new owner, Gila Baruch, who is renting restaurant from Paege; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Although the stakes were not as high as in the uprising of the 20,000 female shirtwaist workers in 1909 or the divisive New York City teachers' strike of 1968, the four-year strike against the Box Tree restaurant also earned a page in the annals of...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the weeks before Election Day, candidates routinely flood the mail with everything from pamphlets to buttons, oven mitts and sponges, but this year Gov. John G. Rowland has proposed sending something special: checks for as much as $200 to almost every taxpayer in Connecticut. Governor Rowland, a Republican who is up for re-election in November, unveiled his latest budget proposal today, taking a bold political step that few governors have dared. He called for a one-time tax rebate that would return $125 million of a state surplus that is projected to be at least $180 million.

headline.main: Tax Rebate Is Proposed In Connecticut

docs.abstract: Gov John G Rowland of Connecticut unveils his latest budget, which calls for one-time tax rebate that would return $125 million of state surplus that is projected to be at least $180 million; Rep Barbara B Kennelly, Democrat who is callenging Rowland for re-election, calls rebate 'political gimmick' in election year; Rowland proposes biggest spending increase in his four years in office, increase of at least 3.5 percent from projected spending for fiscal year that ends June 3; Rowland also calls for borrowing at least $344 million more than previously budgeted; Democrats note Rowland would need to borrow almost double that amount to accomplish his plans, and say it is irresponsible move for state that already has highest per capital debt in nation (M)
docs.snippet: In the weeks before Election Day, candidates routinely flood the mail with everything from pamphlets to buttons, oven mitts and sponges, but this year Gov. John G. Rowland has proposed sending something special: checks for as much as $200 to almost...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Green began a statewide tour yesterday to announce what many have long considered to be a political given: that he is once again seeking the Democratic endorsement to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the man who decisively defeated him in 1986 and who has continued to serve as his preferred symbol of cronyism. This time, Mr. Green asserted, the dynamics are drastically different. First as New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner and now as its Public Advocate, he said, he has spent the last decade battling the tobacco industry, the garbage cartels and lax city agencies that fail its residents. At the same time, he said, Mr. D'Amato has only strengthened his reputation as ''an ethically challenged, hypocritical incumbent.''

headline.main: Green Goes on Tour in His Bid to Oppose D'Amato

docs.abstract: Mark Green says he will seek Democratic endorsement to challenge Sen Alfonse M D'Amato, man who decisively defeated him in 1986; says he has better chance this time, having spent last decade as New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner and now as its Public Advocate; calls D'Amato 'ethically challenged, hypocritical incumbent'; Green must first defeat his Democratic rivals for nomination, Geraldine A Ferraro and Rep Charles E Schumer; Green restates his vow to run clean, positive campaign; he calls on Ferraro and Schumer to share his pledge to show unified Democratic front on day after primary and to avoid 'negative slanders' that marred 1992 primary race; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Mark Green began a statewide tour yesterday to announce what many have long considered to be a political given: that he is once again seeking the Democratic endorsement to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the man who decisively defeated him in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc. said today that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 5 percent before gains as profit from its international and retirement services units overcame rising costs in its managed health care business. The company swung to net income from a net loss. Earnings before gains from investment sales rose to $142.6 million, or 87 cents a diluted share, from $136.2 million, or 81 cents a share, a year ago. The results were in line with analysts' estimates.

headline.main: Aetna Returns to Profitability in Quarter and Its Shares Rise

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc says earnings in fourth quarter rose 5 percent; earnings before gains from investment sales rose to $142.6 million from $136.2 million a year ago; revenue climbed almost 7 percent, to $4.8 billion from $4.5 billion; Aetna shares rise $2.75, to $79.1875 (S)
docs.snippet: Aetna Inc. said today that earnings in the fourth quarter rose 5 percent before gains as profit from its international and retirement services units overcame rising costs in its managed health care business. The company swung to net income from a net...

docs.lead_paragraph: In what appears to be a move to emphasize profitability over the size of its membership rolls, Oxford Health Plans asked the New York State insurance department yesterday to allow it to raise premiums at least 50 percent on the individual coverage it sells to 55,000 New Yorkers, the insurance department said. Separately, a group of Manhattan doctors filed for arbitration proceedings yesterday, as expected, over late payments from the company.

headline.main: Oxford Health Asks Rate Rise in New York

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans asks New York State insurance department to allow it to raise premiums at least 50 percent on individual coverage it sells to 55,000 New Yorkers; increase, for someone who buys coverage directly, could amount to at least $100 more a month; group, known as New York County Medical Society, asks that arbitrator order Oxford to pay what they say is tens of millions of dollars owed to doctors in medical claims and that arbitrator require company to establish clearer payment guidelines (M)
docs.snippet: In what appears to be a move to emphasize profitability over the size of its membership rolls, Oxford Health Plans asked the New York State insurance department yesterday to allow it to raise premiums at least 50 percent on the individual coverage it...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tucked carefully into a pine forest, bathed in the sparkling Siberian air and filled with enough amenities to make a country club look Spartan, the Pediatric Tuberculosis Center here seems to sit on the cutting edge of Russian medicine. In a nation whose Government has concluded that half of the hospitals are too dilapidated to function, the center is in the midst of a robust development program. It has a dozen buildings, a school for patients and a staff of 134.

headline.main: Citadel of Russia's Wasteful Health System

docs.abstract: Russian system of funding hospitals based almost soley on number of beds, without regard to whether they are needed or how they are used, has led to system of over-staffed, often dilapidated hospitals with few patients; 88 hospitals in Tomsk, a citadel of health-care waste in Siberia, serve population of only 500,000; waste comes at time when Russia faces surge in infectious and parasitic diseases and constant growth in cases of major diseases; map; photo (M)
